This IRM incorporates IR pay-setting rules formerly found in IRS Payband System Pay Administration Guidance, interim guidance memorandum HCO-06-0218-0005, Interim Guidance for Determining IRS Official Post of Duty (POD) based on Employee-Initiated Temporary POD Changes, issued September 18, 2018, and supersedes IRM 6.531.1, Pay Under the General Schedule, issued March 26, 2010.

) Purpose: This IRM provides Servicewide policy, standards, requirements, guidance relating to pay under the General Schedule (GS) and the IRS and Payband System (IR). This IRM must be read and interpreted in accordance with pertinent law, governmentwide regulations, Treasury Human Capital Issuance System (HCIS) Directives, and applicable case law. As required, guidance will be supplemented periodically by interim guidance from the IRS Human Capital Office (HCO). (

) Audience: Unless otherwise indicated, the policies, authorities, procedures, and instructions contained in this IRM apply to all business units. Bargaining Unit (BU) employees should review negotiated agreement provisions relating subjects in this IRM. (
) Policy Owner: IRS Human Capital Officer. (
) Program Owner: The Human Capital Office (HCO), Worklife, Beneﬁts and Performance (WBP) Division, Awards, Compensation and Leave Policy Branch. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The HCO, Employment, Talent and Security (ETS) Division, Payroll and Personnel Systems (P&PS) Division, and Workforce Relations Division (WRD). (
) Program Goals: Following policy in this IRM will ensure accurate pay for GS and IR employees. It is intended to establish Servicewide procedures and ensure consistent treatment of employees. (

) The ACLP branch develops and deploys policies, materials and programs to increase Servicewide awareness and understanding of GS, IR and GL pay- setting. Additionally, HCO, WBP, collaborates with other HCO organizations and Servicewide stakeholders to support education and outreach activities they relate to GS, IR, and GL pay-setting. (

) The following activities help ensure program success: a. Conducting annual policy reviews; b. Publishing educational articles such as Leaders’ Alerts and IRS Headlines; and c. Maintaining accurate and up-to-date program websites. (

) Annual pay adjustment: The government-wide change to pay schedules provided under
USC
This adjustment is usually effective on the ﬁrst day of the ﬁrst applicable pay period (PP) beginning on or after January
each calendar year. (

) Change to lower grade/ band (CLG): A change of an employee, while tinuously employed, from one grade/band to a lower grade/band. May be competitive or non-competitive and is used interchangeably with demotion termination of temporary promotion. (
) Conversion-out process: The OPM methodology used to determine an ployee’s GS equivalent grade level when the employee leaves a position covered by the IRS Payband System. (
) Demotion: A change of an employee, while continuously employed, from grade/band to a lower grade/band. (
) Department Manager (DM): Second-level supervisory/managerial positions located in IRS campuses (service centers). Previously classiﬁed at the GS-
, and GS-
grade levels, designated by IR Payband code IR-
The minimum rate of the DM Payband is equal to the GS-
step
rate. The maximum rate of the DM payband is equal to the GS-
step
rate. (

) Detail: Temporary assignment (competitive or non-competitive) to a different position with the same or higher maximum underlying rate of basic pay. A detail is for a speciﬁed period and the employee is expected to return to regular duties at the end of the assignment. Pay increases are not for details. In certain circumstances, a detail may be to a position with a maximum underlying rate of basic pay. An employee who is on a detail is sidered, for pay and strength purposes, to be occupying their permanent position of record. Internal Revenue Manual

) Geographic conversion rule: When an employee’s official worksite is changed to a new location where a different pay schedule applies, the ee’s current position must ﬁrst be converted to the applicable pay schedule and rate for the new official worksite, based on the grade and step (or relative position in range) of the position of record before the move and before pro- cessing applicable pay setting rules. (

) Highest applicable rate range: The rate range applicable to a GS, GL, or IR employee based on position and official worksite that provides the highest rates of basic pay, excluding any retained rates. (

) Highest previous rate (HPR): Highest underlying rate or LEO special base rate previously paid to an individual while employed as a civilian in any in a branch of the Federal Government, without regard to whether that position was under the GS pay system. (
) IRS Payband System (IR Payband or IR): The performance based classiﬁca- tion and pay system established under
USC Chapter
, Personnel Flexibilities Relating to the Internal Revenue Service, outlined in OPM criteria, that covers all IRS managers including SM, DM, and FM, referred to as band instead of grade. (

Locality pay percentage: The percentage authorized for a locality pay area under 5 CFR 531.603, which is used to compute a locality payment (before applying any maximum pay limitations under 5 CFR 531.606).
General Schedule and IRS Payband page (
) Locality rate: A scheduled annual rate of pay (GS, IR, or LEO special base rate if applicable) plus any applicable locality payment. (
) Maximum payable rate (MPR): The highest rate at which an employee’s may be set when HPR is considered. MPR may not exceed the maximum step/rate of the employee’s current grade/band. (
) MPR rule: The rule that allows setting pay for an employee at a rate above rate that would be established using other rules. (
) Official worksite: The official location of the employee’s position of record, determined in IRM
Also referred to as official post of duty and official duty station. (

) Payable rate: The highest rate of basic pay (including locality or special to which an employee is entitled based on the employee’s position of record, official worksite, and step (or relative position in range), or, if applicable, a retained rate. (
) Payband: A pay structure containing one or more GS grade and related ranges of pay. The rate range of a Payband is deﬁned by the minimum rate pay and the maximum rate of pay for that band. (

) Pay event: Any increase in underlying rate of basic pay, including a ‘zero’ increase, received by an employee resulting from a performance-driven review (performance-based increase (PBI)) or as a result of a personnel including promotion, reassignment or demotion into the payband. (

) Pay schedule: A set of rate ranges established for GS, GL, and IR A pay schedule covers a deﬁned category of employees based on coverage conditions (e.g., official worksite, pay plan, occupation). (

) Performance based increase (PBI): An increase in base pay based on an employee’s performance, as measured by their annual summary evaluation. The PBI replaces the annual GS across-the-board increase, within-grade increases (WGIs), and quality step increases (QSIs). The PBI is effective on the same date as the GS annual pay adjustment, which is generally effective the ﬁrst full pay period (PP) in January. (
) Permanent position: A position ﬁlled by an employee whose appointment is one year (
days) or more. For purposes of a WGI, a permanent position includes a position to which an employee is promoted on a temporary basis at least one year. (

) Position of record: An employee’s official position, deﬁned by grade/band, occupational series, employing agency, LEO status, and any other condition that determines coverage under a pay schedule (other than official worksite), as documented on the employee’s most recent Notiﬁcation of Personnel (Standard Form (SF)
) and current position description. A position to which an employee is temporarily detailed is not documented as a position of (

) Promotion: Movement from one grade/band to a higher grade/band while tinuously employed (including such a movement in conjunction with a For IR, movement must be to a position with a higher maximum underlying rate of basic pay.
Under the General Schedule and IRS Payband 6.531.1
Locality rate: A scheduled annual rate of pay (GS, IR, or LEO special base rate if applicable) plus any applicable locality payment.

Position of record: An employee’s official position, deﬁned by grade/band, occupational series, employing agency, LEO status, and any other condition that determines coverage under a pay schedule (other than official worksite), as documented on the employee’s most recent Notiﬁcation of Personnel (Standard Form (SF) 50) and current position description. A position to which an employee is temporarily detailed is not documented as a position of record.
6.531 Pay Under the General Schedule

) Quality step increase (QSI): An increase in an employee’s rate of basic pay from one step of an employee’s GS or GL grade to the next higher step of grade. The purpose of a QSI is to provide appropriate incentives and tion for excellence in performance by granting faster than normal step increases. (

) Rate of basic pay: The rate of pay ﬁxed by law or administrative action for a position held by an employee before any deductions. Rates of basic pay the IRS include the underlying GS rate, LEO special base rate, GS locality rate, special rate, IR underlying rate of basic pay, IR locality rate, and a retained rate, but exclusive of additional pay of any other kind. (

) Rate range or range or rates: A salary range with only two ﬁxed points for setting pay, a minimum and maximum rate, within an established pay schedule, excluding any retained rate. A rate range may consist of GS, IR, LEO special base rates, locality rates, special rates or, for non-GS similar rates under other legal authority. (

) Reassignment: A permanent movement from one position to another without promotion or demotion while serving continuously in the same agency. For movement must be to a position with the same maximum underlying rate of basic pay. (
) Reemployment: Employment, including reinstatement or another type of ap- pointment, after a break in service of at least one full workday. (
) Retained rate: A rate above the maximum rate of the rate range applicable an employee, which is payable under
CFR Part
, Grade and Pay Retention, or, for a former member of the SES, under
CFR
) Senior Manager (SM): First-level supervisory/managerial positions that directly to a member of the SES and second-level supervisory/managerial positions. Previously classiﬁed at the GS-
and GS-
grade levels. The Payband is designated by IR Payband code IR-

CFR Part
, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention, or a similar rate for GS employees established under other legal authority (e.g.,
USC
, Increases in rates of basic pay). The term special rate does not include a LEO special base rate. Note: Special salary rates do not apply to IR rates. (
) Special rate schedule: A pay schedule established under
CFR Part

, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention, to provide higher rates of pay for speciﬁed categories of GS positions or employees at one or more grades or levels or a similar schedule established for GS employees under other legal authority (e.g.,
USC
, Increases in rates of basic pay). (

) Special rate supplement: The portion of a special rate paid above an ee’s GS rate. However, for a LEO special base rate, who is also entitled to a special rate, the special rate supplement equals the portion of the special paid above the officer’s LEO special base rate.
Reemployment: Employment, including reinstatement or another type of pointment, after a break in service of at least one full workday.
General Schedule and IRS Payband (
) Stacked promotion: A stacked promotion occurs when an employee on a temporary promotion receives a second temporary promotion to a graded position. (
) Telework: Permits the employee to work at an approved alternate worksite instead of the location of the employee’s official worksite. (
) Temporary promotion: A time-limited promotion with a not-to-exceed (NTE) date or a speciﬁed term. (

) Transfer: A change of an employee, without a break in service of one full workday, from one branch of the Federal Government (executive, legislative, judicial) to another or from one agency to another. (

) Underlying GS rate, underlying rate, underlying rate of basic pay, IR derlying rate, or IR underlying rate of basic pay: A rate of pay which excludes locality rates and special rates, also referred to as base pay. (
) Waiting period: The minimum time requirement of creditable service to become eligible for consideration for a WGI. (
) Within-grade increase or step increase (WGI): A periodic increase in an ployee’s rate of basic pay from one step of the grade of their position to the next higher step of that grade. (

) The IRS may use the superior qualiﬁcations and special needs pay-setting authority to set pay for a newly appointed employee above the minimum rate (step

for GS) of the highest applicable rate range for the following: a. A ﬁrst appointment (regardless of tenure) as a civilian employee of the Federal Government; or b. ) The employee must meet one of the two superior qualiﬁcations or special needs pay-setting authority criteria outlined below before this authority can used. Each candidate’s qualiﬁcations must be evaluated on an individual a. The candidate must have unusually high (superior) qualiﬁcations for the position to be ﬁlled based on the level, type, or quality of the skills or competencies demonstrated or obtained through experience and/or education. The candidate’s skills, competencies, experience, education, and/or accomplishments must be relevant to the of the position to be ﬁlled and be signiﬁcantly higher than those required; or b. The candidate must have a unique combination of education and ence that meets a special need of the IRS. The experience that is the basis for setting pay at the higher rate must be closely related to the work of the position being ﬁlled and must be essential to accomplishing an important agency mission, goal, or program activity. A candidate may meet the special needs criteria by meeting agency workforce as documented in the agency’s strategic human capital plan. (

HPR given the employee’s length of service spent at the grade/band from which demoted, the grade/band of the demotion, and any intervening grades/ bands. Application of the MPR rule is not required by statute or regulation. It allows the IRS to set pay for employees at a higher rate than would normally be es

tablished, based on a higher rate of pay previously received in another Federal job. The rate derived from this MPR is known as HPR. In some circumstances, the MPR rule may be used to determine an employee’s rate of basic pay upon reemployment, transfer, reassignment, promotion, demotion, change in type of appointment (e.g., conversion), movement from a non
GS pay system, or upon termination of grade/band or pay retention. When an employee is reinstated/reemployed, pay is set considering the em
ployee’s experience and qualiﬁcations. An employee will be afforded the beneﬁts of the MPR rule if the prior Federal work experience and qualiﬁcations
